Dear Mr. Akers:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel at (616) 204-
6992.

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CI411000929
Licensee Group Organization: Pine Rest Christian Mental Health Services
Licensee Designee: Jessica Lynn Kross
Chief Administrator: Cody Akers
Agency Name: Lotus Treatment Program
Agency Address: 300 68th St SE
Grand Rapids, MI 49548-6927
License Status: Regular
License Expiration Date: 12/10/2025
Capacity: 28

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109 Program Statement.
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents’ needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
1

Allegation Youth was refusing to return to the facility from the van and staff
buckled the youth onto a gurney and then restrained the youth.
Investigation Interviews:
The complainant is this consultant as during review of an incident
report it was documented Youth A was transported on a gurney
during a restraint.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility, on
December 20, 2023. Youth A said she is currently placed at Lotus
Treatment Program. Youth A said on December 11, 2023, she was
allowed to go for a walk on campus with Lotus Staff 2 and another
staff. Youth A said while on the walk she started to “run to the
highway” because she “wanted to get hit by a car”. Youth A said
she was restrained by Lotus Staff 2 and the other staff in the grass
by the road. Youth A said “seven” staff showed up and picked her
up and carried her to a van and placed her in a seat. Youth A said
the staff then continued to hold her while in the van. Youth A said
once back at the Lotus Treatment Program building, she got out of
the van willingly and immediately attempted to run back towards
the road at which time two staff members, she was unable to
remember who, placed her in a restraint. Youth A said she refused
to get up and staff were holding her face-up on the ground. Youth
A said additional staff came over to her with a gurney and lowered
it to the ground and the staff picked her up and placed her on the
gurney. Youth A said she was strapped down with “seventeen
straps” that were just like seatbelts. Youth A said she tried to get
out and was able to unbuckle one of the straps, so staff held her
while they rolled her to the unit. Youth A said once on the pod staff
held her for “a long time” and then “finally let go” and she got up
and off the gurney. Youth A said she had never seen a gurney
used prior to or after that incident. Youth A said she has never
heard any other youth talking about being placed on a gurney.
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face at the facility, on
December 20, 2023. Youth B was placed at Lotus Treatment
Program on August 28, 2023. Youth B said she has never seen a
youth on a gurney while at Lotus Treatment Program. Youth B said
she has never heard any youth talking about being placed on a
gurney.
Youth C was interviewed face-to-face at the facility, on
December 20, 2023. Youth C was placed at Lotus Treatment
Program on November 16, 2023. Youth C said she witnessed
Youth A being brought into the unit on a gurney. Youth C said the
staff lowered the gurney, unbuckled her, she got off the gurney
and began to beat up a staff. Youth C said this was the only time
2

she has ever seen the gurney used. Youth C said she has never
heard of the gurney being used with any other youth.
Hospital Nurse Director was interviewed face-to-face at the
facility, on December 20, 2023. Hospital Nurse Director said he
is the director of Nursing for the hospital and residential programs
and in that role responds to code calls within those programs.
Hospital Nurse Director said Pine Rest uses “code green” when a
resident is causing risk to harm themselves or others and the staff
need assistance in order to ensure the safety for the resident or
staff. Hospital Nurse Director said when code green is called each
unit within that building will send someone to respond and assist.
Hospital Nurse Director said on December 11, 2023, a code green
was called an ambulance bay six. Hospital Nurse Director said as
he was running out to the area he saw a staff, who he could not
remember who, pushing out the gurney. Hospital Nurse Director
said when he arrived Youth A was being physically restrained on
the ground between the ambulance bay and the road. Hospital
Nurse Director said staff were offering Youth A to stand up and
walk back to the unit or sit and talk to them however she was
refusing all offers. Hospital Nurse Director said staff lowered the
gurney, stood Youth A up, sat her on the gurney, placed her legs
on it, and buckled her on it. Hospital Nurse Director said there are
five straps that are the same style as a seatbelt. Hospital Nurse
Director said staff continued to have to hold Youth A as she was
unbuckling the straps and they do not move the gurney unless all
straps are buckled for safety reasons. Hospital Nurse Director said
Youth A was wheeled onto her unit, gurney was lowered, all straps
were unbuckled, the staff stood Youth A up and then released her.
Hospital Nurse Director said Youth A was offered a PRN
medication by a nurse who she then began to assault. Hospital
Nurse Director said he and all Pine Rest Safety Specialists are
trained to use the gurney however it is not something they train
the Lotus Treatment Program staff as it is not a tool they would
use on their units or without him or the Pine Rest Safety
Specialists. Hospital Nurse Director said the gurney is stored in
the ambulance bay and not on any unit. Hospital Nurse Director
said a gurney is not standard equipment that is brought to a code
call. Hospital Nurse Director said the use of the gurney was done
correctly and a safe method to transport Youth A back to her unit.
Lotus Staff 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility, on
December 20, 2023. Lotus Staff 1 said he received a call from
Lotus Director on December 11, 2023, that Youth A was on a walk
and trying to run into 68th Street. Lotus Staff 1 said he drove to the
area and upon arrival saw Youth A in a supine restraint in the
3

grass by the sidewalk. Lotus Staff 1 said Youth A was making
statements about wanting to run to the road to be hit by a car.
Lotus Staff 1 said the Pine Rest security guards were present and
had the van, so it was decided to have her transported back to the
Lotus Treatment Program building in the van. Lotus Staff 1 said
Youth A had agreed to get in the van and therefore was released
but immediately made an attempt to run to the road and so was
placed in a two person standing restraint and staff shuffled slowly
when Youth A was willing to walk to the van where she got in
willingly and staff sat on either side of her and held each of her
arms for safety. Lotus Staff 1 denied Youth A ever being picked up
or carried to the van. Lotus Staff 1 said Youth A was driven back to
ambulance bay six which is a door near Lotus Treatment Program
units. Lotus Staff 1 said Youth A continued to make threats about
running to the road as soon as the van doors were opened and so
the staff called code green and waited for additional staff to arrive
prior to opening the van doors. Lotus Staff 1 said staff opened the
van doors and Youth A got out with staff close to her and she
started to run and so was immediately placed in a two-person
standing restraint however Youth A dropped her weight and so the
staff transitioned into a seated restraint. Lotus Staff 1 said a staff
member, who he could not remember, brought over the gurney,
and lowered it down, Youth A stood up with staff on each side, sat
on the gurney and began to resist staff and therefore was held in a
seated hold as the gurney was positioned in a chair like angle.
Lotus Staff 1 said Hospital Nurse Director and another staff took
over and were buckling the seatbelts around Youth A and holding
her to the gurney. Lotus Staff 1 said he walked behind the gurney
as the other staff and Hospital Nurse Director wheeled Youth A
back to her unit. Lotus Staff 1 said once in the unit the gurney was
lowered and seatbelts were unbuckled, and Youth A was released.
Lotus Staff 1 said Youth A immediately began to attack another
staff and had to be restrained once again. Lotus Staff 1 said he
has never used or seen any other staff use a gurney. Lotus Staff 1
said there is not a gurney stored on Lotus Treatment Program
units. Lotus Staff 1 said he has never been trained on the use of a
gurney. Lotus Staff 1 said from what he observed it was a very
safe way to transport Youth A from outside into the unit. Lotus Staff
1 said he was trained when a youth is outside and refuses to
come back inside, to talk to the youth and “wait them out” for a
long as you can trying to verbally get them to agree to go back to
the unit, and if that does not work or it becomes unsafe to call the
clinical manager and/or an ambulance depending on the situation.
Lotus Staff 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility, on
December 20, 2023. Lotus Staff 2 said Youth A arrived at the
4

facility and was on a two-week safety period, then immediately
into a seven-day reflection period due to unsafe behaviors and
had been doing well for ten days and was off her reflection status
so staff wanted to do something for Youth A to show her all her
hard work and good choices was not for nothing. They decided to
take her on a walk around Pine Rest property. Lotus Staff 2 said
she and another staff took Youth A for a walk to the duck pond and
when it was time to return to the unit, Youth A refused and kept
saying she “was not going back”. Lotus Staff 2 said she told Youth
A she could chose the route to walk back, allowed a few more
minutes, encouraged her that they would be able to go for another
walk another day if they follow expectations and return to the unit,
however none of these tactics worked and Youth A began to walk
and then run to 68th street. Lotus Staff 2 said she called Lotus
Director and told him Youth A was running towards the road. Lotus
Staff 2 said Youth A continued to proceed directly to 68th street
saying she was going to get hit by a car. Lotus Staff 2 and the
other staff placed Youth A into a standing two-person restraint in
the grass next to the sidewalk and road. Lotus Staff 2 said Lotus
Director and another staff member arrived to help stabilize the
hold and Youth A dropped her weight. They transitioned into a
seated hold. Lotus Staff 2 said she and Lotus Director were talking
to Youth A and giving her choices to walk to the van or back to the
unit and Youth A refused and kept saying she was going to get into
traffic. Lotus Staff 2 said Youth A willingly stood up and they did a
reverse walk to the van and placed her in a set and then picked up
her feet and placed them in the van. Lotus Staff 2 said there were
other staff that rode with Youth A back to the Lotus Treatment
Program building and she was in a different vehicle. Lotus Staff 2
said when they arrived at ambulance bay six Youth A was sitting
the van with a staff on either side of her and she was refusing to
go into the building. Lotus Staff 2 said Youth A willingly got out of
the van but then attempted to get back to the road and was placed
in a restraint. Lotus Staff 2 said a staff from another unit brought
out the gurney. Lotus Staff 2 said she was not a part of the
restraint at ambulance bay six or putting Youth A on the gurney.
Lotus Staff 2 said she walked behind the gurney as other staff
held Youth A and wheeled her back to the unit. Lotus Staff 2 said
once on the unit, staff unbuckled the straps and let Youth A stand
up, at which times she attacked another staff and had to be placed
in another restraint. Lotus Staff 2 said she has not been trained on
using a gurney however it appeared to be a safe way to move
Youth A from outside back into the unit. Lotus Staff 2 said there is
no gurney on Lotus Treatment Program units to her knowledge.
Lotus Staff 2 said she has never seen the gurney used and it is
not part of the behavior management they use. Lotus Staff 2 said
5

when a youth is refusing to do something they are asked, they are
trained to use verbal de-escalation, process what they are feeling,
and use QBS transport/escort if they need to move the youth.
Lotus Staff 3 was interviewed via telephone on December 27,
2023. Lotus Staff 3 said she is a second shift assistant supervisor
for Lotus Treatment Program. Lotus Staff 3 said she was driving
into Pine Rest on December 11, 2023, for her shift when she saw
Youth A being restrained next to 68th street by Lotus Staff 2, Lotus
Director, and two other staff. Lotus Staff 3 said she stopped to
assist, and as she was walking over to Youth A, she dropped her
weight and staff transitioned from a standing two-person restraint
to a supine restraint on the ground. Lotus Staff 3 said additional
Pine Rest staff arrived for support including the security personnel
and their van. Lotus Staff 3 said the van was pulled near Youth A
and she willingly stood up and they escorted her into the van
where a staff sat on either side of her and held her arms for safety.
Lotus Staff 3 denied any staff picking Youth A up and carrying her
to the van. Lotus Staff 3 said she went back to her own car and
followed the van to ambulance bay six. Lotus Staff 3 said she got
out of her car and went over to the van and was informed
additional staff were coming from the inpatient hospital to assist.
Lotus Staff 3 said Youth A got out of the van and appeared like she
was going to walk on her own inside and then attempted to run
back towards the street at which time she was placed in a
standing hold but immediately dropped her weight and was placed
in a supine hold. Lotus Staff 3 said staff from different units arrived
and Youth A stood up, sat on the gurney and then Hospital Nurse
Director, Pine Rest Safety Specialist, and Hospital Nurse
Supervisor took over and buckled Youth A to the gurney and held
her as they wheeled her into the building and on the unit. Lotus
Staff 3 said she followed and once on the unit the staff unbuckled
her and allowed her to get off the gurney. Lotus Staff 3 said Lotus
Treatment Program staff are not trained and do not use the
gurney. Lotus Staff 3 said it appeared to be a safe way to transport
Youth A back into the unit. Lotus Staff 3 said training for Lotus
Treatment Program staff in this situation would be to use verbal
de-escalation, physical restraints if warranted, wait the youth out
and attempt to convince her to come back inside, and call the
clinical manager for support and direction if needed.
Hospital Nurse Supervisor was interviewed via telephone on
December 27, 2023. Hospital Nurse Supervisor said she is the
supervisor for the inpatient hospital, and not assigned to Lotus
Treatment Program however has assisted in passing medications
or with nursing activities on occasion. Hospital Nurse Supervisor
6

said she responded to the code green call, along with Pine Rest
Safety Specialist. Hospital Nurse Supervisor said they brought the
gurney to ambulance bay six as the call was for assistance to
transport Youth A back to her unit. Hospital Nurse Supervisor said
upon arriving at the incident Youth A was in a restraint on the
ground, attempting to bite and fight against the staff. Hospital
Nurse Supervisor said the staff restraining Youth A got her to stand
and then sit on the gurney at which time she, Pine Rest Safety
Specialist, and Hospital Nurse Director secured the straps on
Youth A and wheeled her back to her unit. Hospital Nurse
Supervisor said once on the unit the straps were unbuckled and
Youth A refused to get up but once she did, she began assaulting
another staff and was placed in another restraint. Hospital Nurse
Supervisor said transporting Youth A on the gurney was a safe
method of moving her especially since Youth A kept trying to drop
her weight and refuse to walk. Hospital Nurse Supervisor said she
is trained in the use of a gurney and has used one previously on
the hospital wing. Nurse Supervisor said the straps on the gurney
have seatbelt buckles on them and anyone can undo the buckles
easily. Hospital Nurse Supervisor said she has never seen the
gurney being used at any other time when she has helped on
Lotus Treatment Program units.
Pine Rest Safety Specialist was interviewed via telephone on
December 27, 2023. Pine Rest Safety Specialist said he works in
the urgent care section of the building and part of his responsibility
is to respond and assist whenever a code is called. Pine Rest
Safety Specialist said he is QBS trained and has training in the
use of a gurney. Pine Rest Safety Specialist said a code was
called to ambulance bay six and when he arrived staff members
had Youth A placed on her back in a restraint. Pine Rest Safety
Specialist said staff were talking to Youth A encouraging her to
stand up and attempted to stand her up however she was fighting
against the staff and refused to stand. Pine Rest Safety Specialist
said another staff member brought over the gurney and lowered it
down next to Youth A and she willingly sat on it, and they lifted her
legs and buckled her onto the gurney. Pine Rest Safety Specialist
said the buckles are like seatbelts and are easily undone and
therefore staff were holding Youth A onto the gurney by her arms
and legs in order to transport her safely back to her unit. Pine Rest
Safety Specialist said once back on the Lotus Treatment Program
unit the gurney was lowered and the buckles were undone, and
Youth A got up and began assaulting a staff and was placed in
another restraint. Pine Rest Safety Specialist said the gurney is a
safe way to transport residents and is used in many units at Pine
7

Rest. Pine Rest Safety Specialist said the gurney is not kept on
Lotus Treatment Program wing or units.
Lotus Director was interviewed face-to-face at the facility, on
December 20, 2023. Lotus Director said Youth A was out for a
walk on Pine Rest property as a result of being good for about ten
days and getting off her reflection status. Lotus Director said he
received a call from Lotus Staff 2 that Youth A began making
statements of suicide and began to run to 68th Street. Lotus
Director said he and the supervisor of the unit immediately drove
out to assist in the situation and when they arrived Youth A was in
a two-person standing hold and was attempting to pull the staff
towards the road. Lotus Director said he and the supervisor stood
between Youth A and the road and attempted to help stabilized the
restraint, so Youth A was not able to move around, and she
dropped her weight and the staff transitioned to a seated hold.
Lotus Director said additional Pine Rest staff arrived, including the
security guards with the van. Lotus Director said he talked to
Youth A about going back and gave her some options, but she
refused and continued to make statements about getting hit by a
car. Lotus Director said Youth A stood up with staff, walked to the
van, and sat in the seat with two staff on either side of her. Lotus
Director said he rode back in a different vehicle and once they
arrived at ambulance bay six Youth A began to fight staff about
going inside. Lotus Director said he ran inside to remove the other
youth from the unit and open doors so they could get Youth A
inside without having to unlock each door. Lotus Director said he
returned outside once finished and the hospital staff had Youth A
on a gurney and were wheeling her inside. Lotus Director said he
has been trained on the use of a gurney as he was previously a
staff on the hospital wing, noting it is a safe way of transporting
Youth A. Lotus Director said once inside they unbuckled the straps
and released Youth A who began to assault another staff and had
to be placed in another restraint. Lotus Director said Lotus
Treatment Program staff are not trained on the use of a gurney as
it is not part of the behavior management or a tool they would be
using. Lotus Director said the gurney is stored in the ambulance
bay and the Lotus Treatment Program staff most likely do not even
know where to find it. Lotus Director said training for Lotus
Treatment Program staff for this situation would be to use verbal
de-escalation or processing, physical restraint if needed, and call
the police or ambulance as a last resort. Lotus Director confirmed
there is nothing in Lotus Treatment Program policies or
procedures about use of a gurney.
Tour Observation:
8

A tour of the facility occurred on December 20, 2023. Lotus
Treatment Program units were viewed and there was no gurney
present on any of the units or within that wing of the building. The
ambulance bay was toured where the gurney is stored in a room
in that wing. The gurney was viewed, there are five straps with
seatbelt buckles to secure the person and are easily unbuckled.
The straps are placed over the person at the ankles, knees, waist,
and two straps crisscross over the persons chest. This is the only
gurney in the building.
Documents Reviewed:
• MiSACWIS Incident Report 169690213 dated December
11, 2023, regarding the restraint with Youth A attempting to
run into 68th street. The incident report is consistent with
Lotus Staff 2’s interview. There is no report that Youth A
was picked up and carried to the van.
• MiSACWIS Incident Report 169710213 dated December
11, 2023, regarding the restraint with Youth A using the
gurney. The incident report is consistent with staff
interviews.
• MiSACWIS Incident Report 169710215 dated December
11, 2023, regarding the restraint with Youth A immediately
after being released from the gurney. The incident report is
consistent with the staff interviews.
• A review of Lotus Treatment Program’s policies and
procedures was conducted and there is no information or
training on the use of a gurney.
Analysis The facility is in noncompliance with Program Statement. The
facility does not have a policy or procedure for use of a gurney
with Lotus Treatment Program youth.
Technical Assistance
Pine Rest staff working with the Lotus Treatment Program youth in
any capacity, including emergency response, must meet all
requirements for a child caring institution staff member, including
being on the annual employee roster for review.
Conclusion Violation Established
9

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
